title: GNU InetUtils telnetd 11-Year Authentication Bypass: Trivial Root Shell via USER Environment Variable Under Mass Exploitation by rwxrwx Group (CVE-2026-24061, CISA KEV)

timeline.event: Vulnerable code introduced in GNU InetUtils via commit fd702c02 adding %U placeholder in login command template
GNU InetUtils 1.9.3 released containing the vulnerable code; flaw remains undetected for 11 years
Vulnerability discovered by Kyu Neushwaistein (Carlos Cortes Alvarez) and reported
Public disclosure via OSS-Security mailing list; GNU patches released
CVE-2026-24061 officially published; Ubuntu and Canadian Cyber Centre issue advisories
Initial exploitation attempts observed (Phase 1: Probing) from 18-21 unique source IPs
CISA adds CVE-2026-24061 to Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
Exploitation peak: approximately 2,600 sessions per day from rwxrwx threat group across 52 IPs in 16 countries
GreyNoise reports 59% sustained reduction in global Telnet traffic indicating widespread takedown or blocking
CISA federal patch deadline for FCEB agencies

simple_summary.what_happened: An 11-year-old vulnerability was discovered in the GNU InetUtils telnetd service, which is the standard Telnet server on many Linux and Unix systems. The flaw is incredibly simple: an attacker can send a specially crafted login request that tells the server to skip password authentication entirely and grant immediate root access. The vulnerable code was introduced in 2015 and went undetected until January 2026. Within days of disclosure, a coordinated threat group began mass exploitation.
simple_summary.who_is_affected: Any Linux or Unix system running GNU InetUtils telnetd versions 1.9.3 through 2.7, including Debian, Ubuntu, Kali Linux, SUSE, and Alpine Linux. Network attached storage devices, embedded Linux systems, OT/industrial control systems, and legacy servers with Telnet enabled are especially at risk. Over 800,000 internet-exposed Telnet services were estimated to be vulnerable at disclosure.
simple_summary.what_attackers_do: Step 1: Attackers scan the internet for systems with Telnet port 23 open and identify those running GNU InetUtils telnetd. Step 2: They establish a Telnet connection and during the protocol option negotiation phase, send a NEW-ENVIRON option with the USER variable set to '-f root' (the -f flag tells the login program to skip authentication). Step 3: The telnetd server blindly passes this value to the /usr/bin/login command, which interprets -f as the 'fast login' flag and root as the username. Step 4: The login program obeys the -f flag and grants immediate root shell access without asking for any password. Step 5: With root access, attackers install backdoors, inject SSH keys for persistent access, harvest credentials, and pivot to other systems on the network.
what_you_should_do: Immediately disable telnetd on all systems where it is not absolutely required: run 'systemctl disable inetd' or remove the inetutils-telnetd package entirely
Update GNU InetUtils to version 2.7-2 or later on systems where telnetd must remain active
Block TCP port 23 (Telnet) at all network perimeters and segment internal networks to prevent lateral Telnet access
Search authentication logs for root logins via telnetd without password authentication: grep 'session opened for user root by telnetd' /var/log/auth.log
Replace Telnet with SSH (OpenSSH) for all remote administration needs across the organization
simple_summary.why_this_is_serious: This vulnerability is arguably the simplest critical exploit in recent memory: a single command grants instant root access with zero authentication. The exploit requires no special tools, no advanced knowledge, and no user interaction. With 800,000+ exposed Telnet services and a coordinated threat group running automated exploitation across 52 IPs in 16 countries, the scale of potential compromise is massive. The 11-year dormancy of this bug in widely-used open-source software raises serious questions about legacy code security in critical infrastructure.

tactics.description: Attackers exploit internet-exposed telnetd services by sending crafted NEW-ENVIRON option with USER=-f root during Telnet protocol negotiation
Telnet service on port 23 provides remote access that is exploited for unauthenticated root access via authentication bypass
The -f flag in the USER variable tricks the login program into bypassing authentication and granting root privileges directly
After gaining root access, attackers inject SSH public keys into authorized_keys files for persistent passwordless access
Attackers create new backdoor user accounts with root privileges to maintain access even if the original vulnerability is patched
Compromised systems serve as pivot points to access other internal network systems via SSH, Telnet, or stolen credentials

detection_guidance.summary: Detection should focus on identifying Telnet connections that result in root access without password authentication, monitoring for the specific NEW-ENVIRON USER=-f attack pattern in network traffic, and searching authentication logs for telnetd-originated root sessions.

log_sources.description: Primary detection source: look for root session openings via telnetd without corresponding password authentication events
Detect Telnet protocol NEW-ENVIRON option containing USER variable with dash-prefixed values (-f, -l, -h) in network traffic
Monitor for TCP port 23 connections from external sources, especially from known exploitation source IP ranges
Monitor for /usr/bin/login process execution with -f flag as argument, which should never occur in normal Telnet authentication

what_to_look_for.indicator: Root login via telnetd without password
what_to_look_for.description: Authentication log entries showing root session opened by telnetd without a preceding password authentication event indicates successful exploitation
what_to_look_for.log_field: grep 'session opened for user root by telnetd' /var/log/auth.log

what_to_look_for.indicator: NEW-ENVIRON USER variable with dash prefix in Telnet traffic
what_to_look_for.description: Network traffic containing Telnet NEW-ENVIRON option with USER value starting with '-' character (e.g., -f root) is a definitive exploitation attempt
what_to_look_for.log_field: Telnet payload: FF FA 18 00 55 53 45 52 00 2D 66 (WILL ENVIRON + USER=-f)

what_to_look_for.description: The /usr/bin/login program being called with -f flag from a telnetd parent process indicates the authentication bypass is being triggered
what_to_look_for.log_field: process='/usr/bin/login' AND args CONTAINS '-f' AND parent='telnetd'

what_to_look_for.indicator: Telnet connections from exploitation source IPs
what_to_look_for.description: Connections on port 23 from IPs in the rwxrwx exploitation infrastructure spanning 16 countries (Hong Kong, USA, Japan, Netherlands, China, Germany, Singapore)

immediate_actions.action: Disable telnetd on all systems immediately
immediate_actions.description: Telnet is an insecure legacy protocol that should not be running in any modern environment. Disable it via: systemctl disable inetd && systemctl stop inetd, or remove the package entirely with: apt remove inetutils-telnetd
immediate_actions.command: systemctl disable inetd && systemctl stop inetd

immediate_actions.action: Block TCP port 23 at all network perimeters
immediate_actions.description: Add firewall rules to block inbound Telnet traffic (TCP port 23) at all internet-facing firewalls and segment internal networks to prevent lateral Telnet access between VLANs.

immediate_actions.action: Update GNU InetUtils to version 2.7-2 or later
immediate_actions.description: On systems where telnetd absolutely must remain active (embedded systems, OT environments), update to the patched version that rejects USER values beginning with dash characters.

immediate_actions.action: Search for evidence of prior compromise
immediate_actions.description: Review authentication logs for any root logins via telnetd without password authentication. Check for unauthorized SSH keys in /root/.ssh/authorized_keys and unexpected user accounts created on systems running telnetd.
immediate_actions.command: grep 'session opened for user root.*telnetd' /var/log/auth.log && cat /root/.ssh/authorized_keys

immediate_actions.action: Replace Telnet with SSH across all systems
immediate_actions.description: Migrate all remote administration from Telnet to SSH (OpenSSH). For legacy systems or OT environments that require Telnet-like functionality, deploy Telnet-to-SSH gateways with proper authentication.
immediate_actions.command: apt install openssh-server && systemctl enable ssh && systemctl start ssh
